intro: Viola hirta var. subciliata, commonly known as the hairy violet, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring hairy stems and heart-shaped, dark green leaves with toothed edges. The plant produces small, violet or purple flowers with five petals, often with a distinctive white or yellow mark at the base. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers bloom in early spring, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
